questions.text: 1. An infant was brought to the pediatrician with complaints of loose stools. The transmission electron micrograph of the causative agent is given in the image below. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the electron micrograph image is suggestive of rotavirus.

Rotavirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded (ds) RNA virus. Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. It has 11 segments of double-stranded RNA. They exhibit genetic reassortment due to the presence of this segmented RNA.



Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 months of age. The incubation period is 1-3 days. Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance. Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens.

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a potential risk of intussusception, especially when the first dose of these vaccines is given to infants aged >12 weeks. Because of this risk, the rotavirus vaccine is not a part of catch-up immunization programs.

Other options:

Option A: Adenovirus contains double-stranded DNA. They have an icosahedral symmetry with structures known as fibers extruding from the vertices. They have a space vehicle-shaped appearance.



Option B: Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.



Option C: Rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae are bullet-shaped viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: 2. Identify the acid-fast stained organism shown in the below microbiology spotter?
questions.solution:
The image showing filamentous, branching acid-fast rods is suggestive of Nocardia.

Acid-fast bacteria are those that retain carbolfuchsin even after decolorization with hydrochloric acid in alcohol. They appear red, while non acidfast organisms take on the color of the counterstain.

Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and produce urease. They have aerial filament fragments that break into coccobacillary cells.

They are weakly acid-fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin (routine acid-fast stain) and retain when decolorized with 1-4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

They cause nocardiosis, which is an opportunistic infection. The main clinical presentation is pulmonary nocardiosis with cough, shortness of breath, fever, and weight loss. Inhalation is the primary route of bacterial exposure.

Other options:

Option B: Actinomyces are gram-positive filamentous non-acid-fast anaerobic organisms. The below image shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces.



Option C: Mycobacteria are non-branching, acid-fast bacilli. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain. 

The image below shows mycobacteria with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain.



Option D: Isospora Belli with modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain shows a large pink-colored acid-fast oocyst as shown below.



The procedure of Ziehl-Neelsen acid-fast stain:

* Fix smear using heat

* Cover with carbolfuchsin. Stain for 5 minutes over direct flame. Do not permit slides to boil or dry out.

* Rinse with deionized water

* Decolorize in 3.0% acid–alcohol (95% ethanol and 3% hydrochloric acid) until only a faint pink color remains

* Rinse with water

* Counterstain for 1 minute with Loffler’s methylene blue stain

* Rinse with deionized water and let dry

Pearl PM1786: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells. Type of stain | Applications Acidic stains | These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens Basic stains. | Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction. Neutral stains | Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain). Type of stain | Applications Gram stain: | To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red). Acid-fast stain: | Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia. Fluorochrome staining: | Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains: Type of stain | Applications Staining volutin-containing organisms | Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells. Flagella stain | Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella Endospore stain | Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin. Capsule stain | Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli). Silver impregnation | Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire. Silver staining | Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes. Calcofluor white staining | The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba Chance's staining | For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: 3. A 28-year-old woman visited the local WHO camp with fever, headache, and joint pain for a month followed by trouble sleeping, and confusion. She gives a history of some insect bite, followed by the development of a painless chancre at the site. Examination revealed posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood examination shows the following findings. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
African trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness, is an arthropod-borne parasitic disease of humans and other animals. It is caused by protozoa of the species Trypanosoma brucei (shown in the image).

It is seen with an elongated body supporting a longitudinal lateral undulating membrane and a flagellum that borders the free edge of the membrane and emerges at the anterior end as a whiplike extension. The kinetoplast (circular DNA inside the single mitochondrion) is a darkly stained body lying next to the basal body from which the flagellum arises. T. brucei rhodesiense and T. brucei gambiense are indistinguishable morphologically.

The most reliable method for differentiating the trypomastigotes of T. brucei and T. cruzi is by the size of the kinetoplast. T. brucei has a relatively small kinetoplast, while T. cruzi has a larger kinetoplast.

Stages of African sleeping sickness:

Stage I – no CNS involvement

* Painless chancre at the site of bite of Tsetse fly.

* Initially, in the first stage of the disease, there are fevers, headaches, itchiness, and joint pains. This begins one to three weeks after the bite

* Hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy, particularly in the posterior cervical region (Winterbottom’s sign)

* Myocarditis

* Hematological - anemia, moderate leucocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. High levels of immunoglobulins mainly immunoglobulin (IgM) are a constant feature.

Stage II – CNS invasion

* Weeks to months later the second stage begins with confusion, poor coordination, numbness, and trouble sleeping.

* Sleeping sickness, extrapyramidal symptoms, coma, and death

Other options:

Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. It is transmitted by the reduviid bug which is also called the kissing bug or triatomine.

Visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disorder transmitted by the bite of an infected female phlebotomus sandfly in developing countries. The disease is transmitted by sandflies, which inoculate the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestation:

* Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar,

* Cutaneous leishmaniasis,

* Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and

* Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Disease | Causative organism | Vector African trypanosomiasis (Sleeping sickness) | Trypanosoma brucei (Gambiense and rhodesiense) | Tsetse fly South American trypanosomiasis (Chaga’s disease) | Trypanosoma cruzi | Reduvid bug Visceral leishmaniasis/Kala-azar/ dum dum fever/ Black sickness | Leishmania donovani | Sandfly (Phlebotomus/ Lutzomia)

The vector seen in the image is tse tse fly (Glossina species) which is involved in the transmission of sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis) caused by Trypanosoma brucei.

DDT 25% and Dieldrin 18-20% are the insecticides used commonly for the control of tsetse fly. The female does not lay eggs. It gives birth to the larva. The below image shows tsetse fly:



Metacyclic Trypomastigote is the infective form of Trypanosoma cruzi.

Identification of Trypomastigote forms:

* Elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus

* The kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus (postnuclear kinetoplast) and situated at the posterior end of the body

* The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end

* This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of infected vertebrate

* Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

Sandfly: They are also referred to as Phlebotomus. They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever and oraya fever.They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.

They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during night (nocturnal pests). They do not fly for more than 50 yards. They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation. 

The below image shows Phlebotomus:



Below is an image of Reduviid bug:

It is based on the arrangement of the flagella in relation to the position of the nucleus and its point of emergence from the cells.



Stage | Morphological characteristics | Seen in Amastigote | Rounded or ovoid, without any external flagellum.

The nucleus, kinetoplast, and axial filaments can be seen.

The axoneme extends up to the anterior end of the cell | Trypanosoma cruzi and Leishmania as the intracellular form in the vertebrate host. Promastigote | Lanceolate in shape.

Antenuclear kinetoplast- kinetoplast is anterior to the nucleus near the anterior end of the cell, from which flagellum emerges.

There is no undulating membrane | It is the infective stage of Leishmania, found in the insect vector as well as in cultures in­vitro. Epimastigote | Elongated. 

Juxtanuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast placed more posteriorly, close to and in front of the nucleus.

The flagellum runs alongside the body as a short undulating membrane, before emerging from the anterior end. | It is the form in which Trypanosoma brucei occurs in the salivary gland of the vector tsetse fly and Trypanosoma cruzi in the midgut of the vector reduviid bug.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania. Trypo-mastigote | This stage is elongated, spindle-shaped with a central nucleus.

Postnuclear kinetoplast - kinetoplast is posterior to the nucleus and situated at the posterior end of the body.

The flagellum runs alongside the entire length of the cell to form a long undulating membrane before emerging as a free flagellum from the anterior end. | This is the infective stage of trypanosomes found in arthropod vector and in the blood of an infected vertebrate.

Note: This stage is lacking in Leishmania.

questions.text:
4. A patient presents with a vaginal discharge with a fishy odor and no itching. While evaluating the Pap smear of a patient, you come across the following finding. Which of the following organisms can cause this infection?
* Mobiluncus curtisii
* Gardnerella vaginalis
* Candida albicans
* Mycoplasma hominis
* Haemophilus vaginalis
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the pap smear finding are suggestive of bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by Mobiluncus curtisii, Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. Hence, option B is correct.

Clue cells are epithelial cells with a fuzzy border or granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering on their surface is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. It has a malodorous (fishy smell) vaginal discharge with minimal vulval irritation.

Amsel's Criteria is helpful in diagnosing bacterial vaginosis when 3 of the following 4 are present

* Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge

* A pH of vaginal fluid >4.5

* Fishy odor of discharge accentuated by adding 10% KOH-Whiff test

* Presence of Clue cells on microscopy. 

Treatment of sexual partners is not required and symptomatic women are treated with metronidazole or clindamycin.





Pearl PM2069: Vaginal infections

| Bacterial vaginosis | Trichomonas vaginitis | Candidal vaginitis Causative organism | Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis | Trichomonas vaginalis | Candida albicans Aetiology | Increased vaginal pH | Sexually transmitted | Decreased immunity Sexual transmission | No | Yes | No Discharge | Fishy, thin, whitish to gray | Frothy, green | Curdy, white Symptoms | Fishy odour, no itching | Itching and burning | Itching, burning pH | >4.5 | >4.5 | <4.5 Speculum | No vaginal epithelium inflammation | Strawberry cervix | Inflamed-epithelium KOH | Positive Whiff test | The whiff test can be positive. | Pseudohyphae seen. Wet mount | Clue cells. No WBCs seen | Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen | WBCs seen Treatment | Metronidazole or Clindamycin | Metronidazole, treat partner also | Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: 5. A diabetic patient sustained an abrasion wound while working in the field. After a few days, he presents with fever, hemoptysis, and upper lobe pneumonitis, along with a suppurative infection of the wound. Findings of staining and microscopy of samples from the exudate are shown below. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the microscopic finding of gram-negative bacilli with a typical bipolar safety-pin appearance is characteristic of melioidosis.

Melioidosis is also known as Whitmore's disease. It is caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei. Infection is acquired by the contamination of abrasion wounds with soil and water containing the bacilli. Patients with underlying diseases like diabetes mellitus have an increased risk of acquiring the infection.

Clinically, melioidosis presents in two forms.

* Acute - It causes acute pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates or severe necrotizing disease. It can also mimic tuberculosis with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. It may lead to septicemia. Acute cases have a high case-fatality rate. 

* Chronic - It can lead to the development of multiple caseous or suppurative foci, with skin and subcutaneous abscesses. These can lead to lymphangitis and lymphadenopathy. It may involve bones and other internal organs.

On microscopy, small, irregularly staining, gram-negative bacilli can be demonstrated for diagnosis. Methylene blue stain shows a typical bipolar safety pin appearance. ELISA for IgM and IgG antibody, indirect hemagglutination can be also used for diagnosis. Ashdown medium is a culture selective for B. pseudomallei.

The image below shows dry purple-colored wrinkled colonies of B. pseudomallei cultured in Ashdown medium.



Treatment is divided into two stages. An intensive phase of 2 weeks of therapy with ceftazidime (drug of choice) or a carbapenem. This is followed by  12 weeks of oral cotrimoxazole to eradicate the organism and prevent relapse.

Other options:

Option B: Chlamydia psittaci causes psittacosis. Psittacosis can cause mild illness or pneumonia.

Option C: Burkholderia mallei cause glanders disease. It is a gram-negative, irregularly staining bacillus with a beaded appearance. It is usually an equine infection. Human infection is possible and is usually occupational, found among veterinarians and those looking after horses. Acute infection presents with fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge, and severe prostration.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia causes cepacia syndrome. It is rapidly fatal septicemia in cystic fibrosis patients.

Pearl PM0109: Common names of various bacteria

List of common names and scientific names of medically important bacteria: Common name | Scientific name Klebs-Loffler bacillus | Corynebacterium diphtheria Koch week bacillus | Haemophilus aegypticus Tubercle or Koch bacillus | Mycobacterium tuberculosis Hansen’s bacillus | Mycobacterium leprae Eaton agent | Mycoplasma pneumonia Pfeiffer’s bacillus | Haemophilus influenza Friedlander’s bacillus | Klebsiella pneumoniae Glander’s Bacillus | Burkholderia mallei Whitmore Bacillus | Burkholderia pseudomallei

questions.text:
6. A 22-year-old male presented to the dermatology OPD with umbilicated papules on his lower abdomen and inner thighs. History reveals that he is sexually active and the presence of similar lesions on his sexual partner. Microscopic examination of material expressed from the papule shows the following. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?

MCV : Molluscum contagiosum virus
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large (up to 35 μm), ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum where the sexually transmitted type is MCV - 2.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin or mucous membrane caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans. There are 4 types of molluscum contagiosum virus (MCVs) - MCV-1 to -4. The most prevalent is MCV-1 and MCV-2 is most often sexually transmitted.

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

Microscopic examination: Shows cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia with large (up to 35 μm) intracytoplasmic Molluscum bodies (also known as Henderson–Patterson bodies) which are ellipsoid, homogenous inclusions in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum. These bodies contain numerous poxvirus virions.



The below image shows the characteristic skin lesions which is the mainstay for diagnosis.

questions.text: 7. An 8-year-old boy was brought to the emergency room with complaints of continuous watery diarrhea that started 20 hours ago. On examination, he is drowsy and unresponsive. Findings of the microscopic examination of a stool sample are shown in the image below. All the following can be used as a transport medium for this causative organism, except _____.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette consisting of watery stools and the image showing the characteristic fish in stream appearance are suggestive of Vibrio cholerae, for which Stuart media cannot be used as a transport medium. Stuart medium is used as a transport medium for the Neisseria group of organisms.

Transport media for Vibrio cholerae: 

* Venkatraman Ramakrishnan (VR) medium

* Cary Blair medium

* Autoclaved seawater.  

Enrichment media for Vibrio cholerae:

* Alkaline peptone water at a pH of 8.6

* Monsur's taurocholate tellurite peptone water at a pH of 9.2.

Note: Both enrichment media are good transport media as well.

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

* Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S

* Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

Pearl PM0409: Culture media used for Vibrio cholerae

The following are various culture media used for Vibrio cholerae: 

Transport Media

* Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan (VR) medium

* Cary-Blair medium

* Autoclaved sea water

Enrichment Media

questions.text: 8. Which of the following fungi shows the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows germ tube formation (also known as the Reynolds Braude phenomenon), which is seen in Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C.

It is also positive for a relatively new characterized species, Candida dubliniensis.

It is negative in Candida glabrata.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.



After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.



The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.



Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Pearl PM1761: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

* Yeast

* Yeast-like

* Molds

* Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding

* Oval to round forms

* Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.



Yeast like:

* Unicellular fungi

* Reproduces by budding or binary fission

* Spherical or oval forms

* Pseudohyphae may be seen.

* Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.



Molds/filamentous fungi:

* Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate

* Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.

* Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.



Dimorphic fungi

* Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.

* Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

* Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: 9. A 16-year-old boy presented with cyclical fever and chills for the last 7 days. A peripheral blood smear is shown below which shows Schuffner's dots. What is the likely etiology of this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever and chills with the image showing Schuffner's dots in the erythrocyte suggest that P. ovale is the causative agent.

Schuffner's dots are red granules seen on the surface of the trophozoites of P. vivax and P. ovale. It is more evident in P. ovale, it is not always seen in late trophozoites of P. vivax. The infected erythrocytes are enlarged and oval-shaped with fimbriated margins. The schizonts resemble those of P. malariae, except that the erythrocyte is usually oval, with prominent Schuffner's dots and the pigment is darker. 

Other options:

Option A:  Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/ maltese crosses, which are pathognomic of B. microti or B. duncani.



Option C: Anaplasma causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis. It is transmitted by ticks. Clinical features are fever, headache, and myalgia. Inclusions in granulocytes are seen.



Option D: Erythrocytes in P. falciparum initially will show a marginal ring form known as accole. Binucleate rings (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones are commonly seen. The infected erythrocyte is normal in size and shows a few brick-red dots known as Maurer's cleft. Basophilic stippling also can be noted. 

The blood smear in P. falciparum will show multiple ring forms in the erythrocytes as shown below.



Note: Maltese crosses are also seen in the urine of a nephrotic syndrome patient too.

questions.text: 10. A 30-year-old man with chronic osteomyelitis presented with purulent discharge from a wound in his right leg. A swab was collected and Gram staining showed the following finding. Identify the incorrect statement about the causative organism.

choices.text: The organism is tube coagulase positive.
On culture, golden-yellow pigments are produced on nutrient agar.
Beta-hemolysis is seen on blood agar.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the gram stain showing gram-positive cocci in clusters are suggestive of Staphylococcus aureus. The incorrect statement about S. aureus is that it is catalase negative. S. aureus is catalase positive, whereby it can be differentiated from the catalase-negative streptococci.

S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus arranged in grape-like clusters that may cause various pyogenic infections like a carbuncle, furuncle, abscess, osteomyelitis, and even septicemia. On nutrient agar culture, smooth, shiny, easily emulsifiable golden yellow-pigmented colonies (option C) are formed due to the presence of β-carotene. On a nutrient agar slope, the confluent growth presents a characteristic oil-paint appearance. On blood agar, it shows a wide zone of beta (complete) hemolysis with sharp edges. (Option D)

Biochemical tests of S. aureus are as follows:

Staphylococci produce catalase, which converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen and produces bubbles, as shown below.



S. aureus is coagulase positive. The coagulase test can be done using two methods:

*

The tube test detects free coagulase. When 0.1 mL of an agar culture suspension of S. aureus is added to 0.5 mL of human or rabbit plasma in a test tube with an anticoagulant and incubated in a water bath at 37°C for 3–6 hours, the plasma clots and does not flow when the tube is tilted. This shows a tube coagulase-positive test. Prolonged incubation is avoided as the clot may be lysed by the fibrinolysin produced by a few strains.

*

The slide test detects bound coagulase (clumping factor). The bacterial isolate is emulsified with a drop of saline and added with a drop of rabbit or human plasma. A prompt clumping of the cocci is suggestive of a positive test. It should be performed after ensuring the absence of autoagglutination and can be positive for S. aureus and for a few strains of coagulase-negative staphylococcus. 

The below image shows positive and negative tube coagulase tests:



S. aureus are indole negative, methyl red (MR), and Voges-Proskauer (VP) positive. They hydrolyze urea, reduce nitrates to nitrites, and liquefy gelatin.

The organism is also positive for enzymes like nuclease, hyaluronidase, and hydrolase. It produces cytolytic toxins such as hemolysins (α, β, γ, δ), Panton-Valentine leucocidin, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and enterotoxins, which are responsible for staphylococcal food poisoning.

The typing of bacterial strains can be done by phenotypic and molecular methods. Phenotypic methods involve the typing of the strain according to its susceptibility to bacteriophages. This method needed periodic revision of the reference phages and is not used now.

The image below shows the golden yellow colonies of S. aureus:

questions.text: 11. A 60-year-old male patient came with a sharp, severe, constant, burning pain in his right chest. On examination, the lesion is as seen below. Which of the following is the characteristic finding that you would expect to see on microscopy with Tzanck smear in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image showing confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome associated with severe pain is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. Herpes zoster shows multinucleated giant cells on microscopy with Tzanck smear.

Tzanck smear is a cytological examination of skin blisters. After rupturing the roof of the blister, the floor is scraped with a blade and the material is transferred onto a microscopic slide and fixed. Slides are stained with Giemsa, Wright’s stain or toluidine blue and examined under the microscope.

The findings of various disorders on Tzanck smear are as follows: Disorder | Finding Pemphigus | Acantholytic cells Bullous pemphigoid | Predominantly eosinophils Chronic bullous disease of childhood | Predominantly neutrophils Varicella-zoster | Multinucleated giant cells Herpes simplex infection | Multinucleated giant cells Toxic epidermal necrolysis | Necrotic cells Molluscum contagiosum | Henderson Paterson Bodies Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola | Acantholytic cells with Guarneiri Bodies Leishmania | Leishman-Donovan (LD) Bodies

Herpes zoster is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from dorsal root ganglia. An earlier infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain and it may be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dorsal roots. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx. The thoracic dermatomes are most commonly affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

* Painful zoster infections in adults

* Facial zoster at any age

* Immunocompromised

questions.text: 12. A 45-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever and breathlessness for 3 weeks. Chest radiograph shows patchy infiltration in the lower lobes bilaterally and the lung biopsy showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is CMV-associated pneumonia. The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia.



CMV is a β-group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:

* Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection  

* Neonates - devastating systemic infections

* Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)

Other options : 

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis is caused by Aspergillus fumigatus. This can occur in prolonged treatment with steroids or in retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

Option C: Cryptococcal pneumonia is a fungal infection caused by Cryptococcus neoformans predominantly in immunosuppressed individuals and rarely in the immunocompetent population. Pulmonary cryptococcosis in AIDS/ immunosuppressed patients presents as an interstitial lung disease with lymph node enlargement. The histopathological diagnosis is made by identifying encapsulated yeast forms within sections of the inflammatory lung tissue.

Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma and classical TB symptoms.

questions.text: 13. A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe burning with urination for the past 3 days. He has also had a clear urethral discharge. He is sexually active but uses condoms inconsistently. Gram stain of a urethral swab shows neutrophils but no organisms. The organism was isolated on cell culture and a Giemsa stain was done as shown below. Which among the following statements is incorrect regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: It is a facultative intracellular organism.
The elementary body is the infectious form.
McCoy cell line is used to isolate chlamydia.
Infection with this organism can be treated with azithromycin.

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is indicative of urethritis due to Chlamydia trachomatis. Therefore, the incorrect statement is option A. Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular organism.  

Chlamydia is coccobacilli that lack the enzymes for ATP synthesis and are hence dependent entirely on the host cell, making them obligate intracellular organisms (not facultatively intracellular). As they are dependent on host cells for ATP synthesis, they can be grown in McCoy cells. McCoy cells are treated with cycloheximide to isolate chlamydia.  

They can exist in two states-

* Extracellular form called the elementary body. The elementary body is the infectious form.

* Intracellular form called the reticulate body. These reticulate bodies are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the "inclusion body" which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells. The given image shows Giemsa stained urethral discharge smear revealing the cytoplasmic inclusion bodies of Chlamydia.

Different serovars cause a variety of diseases, of which D to K cause genital tract diseases. Serovars A, B, and C cause trachoma while L1, L2, and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum.

The investigation of choice is the nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT). 

Treatment includes antibiotic therapy with azithromycin or doxycycline. Sexual partners should also be treated.

questions.text:
14. Arrange the following steps of the Ziehl-Neelsen staining technique in the correct sequence.

1. Flood with carbol fuchsin 2. Flood slides with 3% acid-alcohol 3. Flood the slides with methylene blue  4. Let stand for 2-3 min 5. Heat the slide with a Bunsen burner flame
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of the steps of Ziehl-Neelsen staining is 1-5-2-4-3 (option A).

Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining is used to detect acid-fast bacteria, eg. Mycobacteria in patients with suspected tuberculosis. The steps of the process are as follows:

* Place slides on the staining rack so they are at least 1 cm apart, and flood with carbol fuchsin.

* Heat the slide to steaming with the flame from a Bunsen burner. Do not let the stain boil or dry. Add additional stain if necessary.

* Wash off the stain with distilled water.

* Flood slides with 3% acid-alcohol.

* Let stand for 2-3 min (more acid-alcohol should be used if the smear is heavily stained).

* Wash off the acid-alcohol with distilled water and tilt the slides to drain.

* Flood the slides with methylene blue and let them stand for 1-2 minutes.

* Wash off the methylene blue with distilled water.

* Tilt the slides to drain.

* Allow slides to air dry in the slide rack. Do not blot.

ZN- stained smears for AFB detection in tuberculosis are grading as follows: Number of AFB per oil immersion field | Grading | Number of fields | Result >10 / field | 3+ | 20 | Positive 1-10 / field | 2+ | 50 | Positive 10-99 / 100 field | 1+ | 100 | Positive 1-9 / 100 field | Scanty | 100 | Positive Nil AFB / 100 field | 0 | 100 | Negative

Note: The World Health Organization (WHO) and NTEP revised the recommended concentration of carbol fuchsin to 1% instead of 0.3%.

questions.text: 15. Which of the given eggs belong to the parasites that can cause autoinfection?
questions.solution:
Among the given options eggs of Strongyloides stercoralis (Image 2) and Enterobius vermicularis (Image 3) belong to parasites that can cause autoinfection.



Autoinfection/self-infection is a mode of transmission where infection can occur by finger-to-mouth transmission (Eg: Enterobius vermicularis) or by internal reinfection (Eg: Strongyloides stercoralis). Parasites that can cause autoinfection include:

* Hymenolepis nana

* Enterobius vermicularis 

* Taenia solium

* Strongyloides stercoralis

* Cryptosporidium parvum

Pearl PM1765: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: 16. A child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain. The stool microscopy image is given below. Eggs were non-bile stained and floated in the saturated salt solution. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the organism?

choices.text: It hatches in the small intestine.
Praziquantel is the drug of choice for infection with this organism.

questions.solution:
The given clinical history along with the given image implicates the most likely organism to be Hymenolepis nana. The incorrect statement is option C.

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the smallest tapeworm. Humans are the definitive host. It has no intermediate host. It occurs more commonly in children and the patient acquires this infection by ingesting food or water contaminated with its eggs. The egg attaches to the intestine and develops into the larva and adult worm. The adult worm resides in the small intestine.  

Patients are usually asymptomatic. But in heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Pruritus may also be present due to an allergic response.

It can also cause autoinfection. Internal autoinfection occurs when the eggs are released in the intestine and hatch there. External autoinfection occurs through the ingestion of the eggs by the fecal-oral route. They hatch in the small intestine to release the hexacanth embryo which penetrates the intestinal villus resulting in autoinfection.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.



The eggs are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution. They have a thin colorless outer membrane and thread-like polar filaments on stool microscopy. They have a hexacanth embryo. 

Treatment is done with Praziquantel (25mg/kg) and is the drug of choice.

Pearl PM1765: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: 17. An HIV-positive male patient comes to the clinic with a complaint of watery diarrhea. He is not on antiretroviral therapy. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. A wet mount of the freshly passed stool of the patient reveals the following picture. What is true about these helminths?

choices.text: Rhabditiform larva is infective for humans
It is usually transmitted through contaminated food and water
Females of these species are ovoviviparous
Drug of choice for treatment is triclabendazole

questions.solution:
The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with watery diarrhea and stool revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis. Females of these species are ovoviviparous is the correct statement.

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous, meaning they release live larvae into the surrounding host tissues. Adult female worms reside in the small intestine, where they lay eggs in the intestinal mucosa. These eggs hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). Some of the rhabditiform larva are excreted in stool, while others develop directly into filariform larvae (L3 stage), which can penetrate the colonic wall causing internal reinfection or perianal skin causing autoinfection. Rhabditiform larvae in the environment mature into infective filariform larvae, which infect others through penetration of the skin of feet. 

The life cycle of Strongyloides is shown below:



It causes cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli, leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms. 

Intestinal manifestations may resemble those of peptic ulcer or of malabsorption syndrome. Mucus diarrhea is often present. Other manifestations are protein-losing enteropathy and paralytic ileus.

Larva currens (racing larvae) is a skin lesion that starts perianally and occurs due to autoinfection. It causes rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks due to the migration of filariform larvae in the skin called, as shown in the image below.



Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the freshly passed stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis. Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels are seen. 

Ivermectin is the preferred agent over albendazole in the management of strongyloidiasis.

questions.text: 18. A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with continuous fever, pallor, and splenomegaly. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the slide showing macrophages infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies point towards a diagnosis is visceral leishmaniasis or kala-azar. It can be established by the rk 39 antigen test. 

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host in developing countries.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

* Visceral leishmaniasis, or kala-azar

* Cutaneous leishmaniasis

* Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis, and

* Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms,

* The promastigote develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and

* The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.

Kala-azar is characterized by persistent fever, anemia, liver and spleen enlargement, and lymphadenopathy.

Diagnosis:

* The microscopic demonstration of amastigotes from bone marrow is the gold standard for the diagnosis of Kala-azar.

* Rapid diagnostic test: rk39 rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip. This is recommended by National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India.

* Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear, bone marrow, lymph node, or splenic aspirate is confirmatory.

* Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.

* Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test, complement fixation test using Witebsky, Klingenstein and Kuhn (WKK) antigen.

* Culture using NNN medium or Schneider's liquid medium to demonstrate promastigote.

* Leishmanin /Montenegro test: Induration of 5mm or more after 48-72 hours indicated prior exposure to leishmanial parasite. It is a delayed hypersensitivity test. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after curing the disease.

Option B: Plasmodium lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) antigen test is used in the diagnosis of malaria.

Option C: Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test done to detect toxoplasmosis.

Option D: ProSpec T is a commercially available ELISA test kit to detect Giardia-specific antigen 65.

The given images show amastigotes in the bone marrow.



Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.

Pearl PM0657: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

* Tests for antigen detection

* Tests for antibody detection

Antigen Detection: Antigen | Parasite Galactose lectin antigen | Entamoeba histolytica Giardia-specific antigen 65 | Giardia lamblia WKK and rk39 antigen | Leishmania donovani HRP-2 antigen | Plasmodium falciparum Vivax-specific pLDH | Plasmodium vivax 200 KD Ag and OG4C3 antigen | Wuchereria bancrofti

Antibody detection:

* Complement fixation test (CFT)

* Indirect hemagglutination test (IHA)

* Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFA)

* Rapid immunochromatography test

* ELISA test

questions.text: 19. All of the following microorganisms have the appearance as shown in the image below except ___________
questions.solution:
The above image shows characteristic bipolar staining giving a safety pin appearance. Clostridium difficile does not show bipolar staining.

questions.text: 20. A child presents with complaints of sore throat and low-grade fever. Examination reveals cervical lymphadenopathy and grey-white discharge covered tonsils. Gram staining showed the following appearance. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the causative bacteria.

choices.text: Albert stain is used for diagnosis
The toxin acts via ADP ribosylation of EF-2
Iron levels regulate the production of toxin

questions.solution:
A child presenting with a sore throat, cervical lymphadenopathy, grey-white discharged covered tonsils and gram stain showing gram-positive rods with clubbed ends, beaded appearance, and Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement is suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheria is not chromosome encoded, it is phage-encoded (tox gene). 

Albert’s stain or Neisser’s stain or Loeffler's methylene blue are used to demonstrate the metachromatic granules of Corynebacterium diphtheria. These granules are called polar bodies as they are situated at the ends of the bacilli. The organism can be cultured in Loeffler's serum slope and Tellurite blood agar.

The image below demonstrates C. diphtheriae in Albert's stain as green bacilli with purple-blue metachromatic granules.



The systemic manifestations of diphtheria are due to diphtheria toxin. It is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) by ADP ribosylation responsible for protein synthesis and the iron level regulates the toxin production.

The clinical manifestation of diphtheria depends on the site of infection. Pharyngeal/faucial diphtheria is the most common presentation. The patient has marked adenitis and a bull neck. Pseudomembrane over the tonsils is characteristic. Bleeding from the tonsils can occur. It leads to life-threatening complications such as asphyxia, circulatory failure, post-diphtheritic paralysis, and toxaemia.

Cutaneous diphtheria may manifest as diphtheritic whitlow or skin ulcer.

The image below shows the pseudomembrane over the tonsil typically seen in diphtheria.



Image below shows bull neck:



Treatment of diphtheria consist of administering diphtheria anti-toxin (20,000 - 100,000 units) and supplementing with antibiotics (penicillin and erythromycin).

B: Botulinum toxin C & D

C: Cholera toxin

D: Diphtheria toxin

E: E.coli(EHEC): Verocytotoxin (Shiga-like toxin)

Increase in cGMP

* Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

* Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Clostridium difficile

* Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S

* Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S
